reviews.review: efsane hikayeli bir oyun ben beÄŸendim sizinde beÄŸeniceÄŸinizi umuyorum
Boring, repetitive, glad to have not paid full price. In addition, could have done without the SJW stuff.

Pros:
- No doubt. Absolute masterpiece. This is the best game for Screenshot and Wallpaper material (good looking, vibrant, beautiful scenery, visually stunning)
- When you play. Maybe You will feel and find the story engaging, confusing, and fun at the same time.
- Story is good. If you compare it to it's predecessor (Bioshock 1 and Bioshock 2), Bioshock infinite has less scarier atmosphere than those 2, and has more plot twist.

Cons:
- Sometimes, sudden fps drop occured. When you play it at steady 60 fps, in the next 15 minutes suddenly your fps drop to 15 and slowly back to 60 and repeat.

Side note:
- In some case or scene. The story contain some strong and weird religious, politics, and ideology. It's not cons at all, but it will be cons for some. If you try the game and find that it disturbing you, you have been warned before.

Do I recommend it? Yes, no doubt. If you agree with pros more than cons above.

*This review contains spoilers*

Bioshock Infinite is a largely praised game (just look at the amount of positive reviews), but in my opinion is mostly just overhyped and is given too much credit for an attempt at mature storytelling; a failed attempt at that.

Now, I wouldn't say that Bioshock 1 and 2 had the deepest, most compelling stories ever but they made sense and they worked. The first two Bioshock games also had the benefit of good atmosphere and fun gameplay, with a variety of ways a player could tackle a fight. I enjoyed both and would recommend them highly.

Infinite, on the other hand, turned out to be very disappointing. I was expecting something great after constantly hearing how amazing the game was. But I played the entire thing and was never really impressed. First, the gameplay. Especially compared to the other games, it was boring. The limit of two guns plus the lack of weapon variety was an awful choice. Hacking is replaced with a temporary vigor, and lockpicking is Elizabeth's domain. You just get to scrounge up the picks. Exploration is limited. You still have to buy upgrades for your weapons, one by one. The sky rails could have been interesting, if they were implemented better. Vigors in the game needed more variety as well, but at least you could have more than two. Combat is pretty easy, and the enemies also lack variety and intelligence. You don't have a chance to set up anything before engaging in battle. The choices given to you are very superficial, and honestly don't have much of an impact. Sometimes all the combat and gameplay just felt like filler in between cut scenes. Why is the third game in the series so much more limiting than the first?

The story is hailed to high heaven, but even that was poorly executed. Characters weren't believable. Story events made little sense. I once saw someone describe Booker as having video game amnesia. As in, he doesn't recall anything at first merely because it's convenient for the story that way. They attempted to touch on mature topics, mostly racism, but didn't manage to do so with any depth or flair. It's shallow. And doesn't go anywhere with these topics. We get that racism is bad. If you're going to make it a topic in your game, maybe it should be done with more nuance than LOOK RACISM BAD in a really hamfisted way.

And the worst part was they included time travel and multiverses. Both are really difficult to implement in a way that makes sense within the story, and it's usually best just to avoid using them altogether. I wish Infinite had avoided them. It was a cheap attempt at depth, and it's pseudo-intellectual. It's own attempts at explaining story events doesn't work. Like, you're told that there are infinite worlds and yet killing one Booker in one world prevents Comstock from ever existing in any world? How, unless that world is the sole birthplace of every other world and every other timeline? Elizabeth would have to kill every Booker in every world forever. Plus, there's the grandfather paradox, and the 'it was you all along' trope. I won't say much more, but matthewmatosis managed to lay out most of the problems I had if you want to check that out.

I feel like Infinite was written by someone who wanted there to be specific scenes and specific events, but was unable to write the story in a way that allowed these to make sense and come together seamlessly. So they resorted to time travel and multi-worlds to give the game a veneer of intellectualism and cover for it's weak points. It relies on deus ex machinas and contrived occurances. It resulted in an ending that did not feel satisfying. It sounds good on the surface, but falls apart when examined. 

I get why people want to like it. It pretended to be a mature story during a time where video games are considered childish. It covered touchy topics. It has a spunky female character. It tries to tug on your emotions. It gave itself a crazy setting (city in the sky). But all of these were just fluff. Flashy without substance.

I wanted so bad to like this game. But no matter how long I played it and tried to find the good things about it besides how nice the graphics were, I just can't say this was a good game.

This is literally a masterpiece of a game
this has story, art, amazing gameplay that you can replay again and again
I can not recommend this game enough 

and not only does this tie into the older bioshock games with the DLC via story, but it is daaaark and soo much worth it
20/10 buy this game and i wish there was more like it with story, amazing graphics and great gameplay like this

this game holy shit this fucking game it hit me hard that ending i wont spoil it but its a twist and a pull on the heart strings so to not talk about the story ill talk about the fps part     PROS- the guns sound meaty and people dont like how you can only hold two weapons but i like it gives a meaning to choosing a weapon - the enemys have a good skill increase but the final boss fight took a biiig difficulty spike for me -the combat suits both tactical players and run n gun doom style players like me - the skylines are one of the best things in this game and in most games - the story is complex meaning that most idiots cant wrap their heads around it and so less shitty fanbase members but seriously though i like the complexity of it - very easy to get immersed in i almost played the entire game in one night - elizabeths AI is very well made and her facial animation holy crap other than the huge eyes i couldent tell that she was a video game character - damn good optimism i could get this game running on my computer so you sure as hell can - i cant think of many cons go talk to somebody who dosent like it i cant think of any big cons - the story and shooting blend together perfectly - and i doubt it but irrashinal games (sorry for mispelling it but im too lazy to fix it) or if anybody has contact with them then please tell them about me because i am a great concept artist and id overall love to meet the people behind one of my favorite games ever

It's okay.

PROS:
+Fun game/gunplay
+Well written story
+Cool locations, the Columbia. This Bioshock takes place in the skies than its predecessors in the sea and there's alot of great places to see and walk around
+Elizabeth, and other fantastically written characters, wait who am I kidding its just Elizabeth. I like Dewitt but Elizabeth is the real shine of the game 
+Great soundtracks and very creative sound effects and cues


CONS:

Isn't linked to Bioshock at all, so why bother name it "Bioshock"?

Auto aim. And there's no option to turn it off.

I don't recommend this game. Eventhough it has an impressive story, the game - the actual game - is little but filler. You basically move from arena to arena fighting the same enemies over and over. There is nothing more to it, sure you can sneak a little, sure you can cause a little more chaos with your powers... yet at the end of the day, the story is what carries this game. And even if you are into multidementional and timetravel topics, even then it shows itself as quality, but quite mediocre as well. It seems complicated, but they made it overcomplicated for the 'wow' effect. I finished the game once, and I just cannot seem to install it again. If you strip away the story, the actual game isn't really that fun for that long. So keep in mind when buying this game that the gameplay is enjoyable, but you will finish it for the story.

I simply hoped it would have been more fun... and not a gun and run game with some quality fiction added to it.

I played BioShock & Bioshock 2 on console years ago and I never got around to playing this one. So when I saw it on a steam sale i snagged it. This game has an excellent story and keeps you entertained all the way through. The battles are a ton of fun, and the music and ambience keeps you engaged. BioShock Infinite is well worth it for the full price of $30 that they normally ask, but because it is over 4 years old I would wait until its on a sale.
